title: Replacement of Service Now with an industry standard reporting system for Beach Lifeguard Operations
description: Service Now Portal was developed in-house. Current system does not compare well to industry standard benchmarks. The licensing with Service Now may likely be more expensive than industry benchmarks. Reporting function is not available and design would unlikely meet industry standard. Uncertainty of the continuation of service now has business critical implications.
businessJustification: Operational Reliability Reduce system downtime risk from unsupported ServiceNow platfor Reduce system response time and functionality by 50% with purpose-built beach management functionality Safety & Compliance: Maintain 100% incident reporting capability with real-time data capture Ensure continuous compliance with beach safety regulations and audit requirements Staff Efficiency: Reduce daily administrative tasks through automated beach operations workflow Eliminate manual workarounds currently required due to ServiceNow limitations Enable mobile-first operations for beach patrol staff 2. Success Metrics/KPIs System Performance: System availability: >99.5% uptime Response time: <2 seconds for critical functions Zero security incidents from unsupported software Operational Metrics: Daily reporting completion: 100% within 30 minutes of shift end Staff training time: <4 hours (vs current complex ServiceNow workflows) End of period reporting 100% improvement  Risk Mitigation: -operational disruptions due to system failure -audit compliance maintenance - complete elimination of unsupported software liability Cost Efficiency: Total cost of ownership comparison: Watchtower example vs continued ServiceNow support Reduction in IT support tickets related to beach operations system Staff productivity gains measured in hours saved per week

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - To compare well with industry standard benchmarks for leisure related benchmarks in leisure related functions

title: Implementation of ticketing system for Caretaking
description: Our current system for reporting repair and maintenance requests for buildings is facing several challenges, leading to customer dissatisfaction and operational inefficiencies. Staff have expressed frustration because they are unable to track the status of their requests, which leads to uncertainty and repeated inquiries. Additionally, there is no system in place to provide automatic updates to staff about the progress of their requests. This lack of feedback results in multiple customers often reporting the same issue, causing duplicated efforts for the Facilities Management Team.  Moreover, we do not have a mechanism to track the types of requests, which hinders our ability to gain insights for asset management and identify trends. This absence of data tracking keeps our approach reactive rather than proactive. The lack of a streamlined process leads to inefficiencies, increased costs, and the risk of requests being lost, missed, or not followed up on.
businessJustification: A decrease in the number of duplicate maintenance requests by at least 40%, an increase in customer satisfaction scores by 20% (measured through post-service surveys), a reduction in maintenance-related costs by 10%, establishment of a complete and accessible record of all service requests and actions taken.

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - To streamline request related to property services

title: Risk, Integrity and Internal Audit
description: Council currently relies on manual information systems, together with its practices and risk management culture, for managing and reporting operational and enterprise risks.  This results in fragmentation of information, which: - reduces Council’s ability to easily recognise key insights, such as emerging Council-wide issues - increases the risk of duplication of effort through staff having to access various information sources to obtain information - slows the ability of senior staff to see and respond to risks across multiple levels, leading to delayed decision-making on key issues - leads to potential ‘silo-ing’ of information, meaning information is not available across business units to inform decision-making - for example, lower level risks being reported via email and not captured in appropriate enterprise systems, and/or issues that relate to significant risks, such as legislative compliance, not being captured and properly escalated  Council has a range of other systems, which are relevant to risk management but not integrated to support risk-informed decision-making – for example: - Sycle/CAMMs contains information about actions for business planning – which should be informed by the risk management framework but has no direct link with top-level risk management reporting or department risk registers (undertaken manually in word and saved in TRIM). - Done Safe as an incident management system contains information about non-conformance hazards (for example, non-compliance with legislation), with information included inconsistently - Local Government Legal provides a delegations and legislative compliance register, containing information about key legislative requirements applicable to local government, but does not integrate with other Council systems to manage compliance risks   Governance Risk and Compliance is a concept referring to an integrated collection of capabilities that enable an organisation to reliably achieve objectives, address uncertainty and act with integrity. In Council, this could capture a range of ‘second line’ functions undertaken by Integrity and Risk, designed to provide assurance for and power an ethical, risk informed and resilient organisation, including risk and compliance management.

requestor.name: Cameron Smith
requestor.department: Governance Risk and Compliance (GRC) technology solution

businessJustification: Risk and compliance management integrated with other relevant systems  Executive satisfaction in insights on top-level risk management  Reduced time spent on risk reporting – currently estimated staff are spending around 50 hours per quarter to prepare top-level risk reporting (including time spent by managers and other staff contributing information, Risk Lead supporting and collating information and individual Executive risk owner review). Additional time is spent on departmental risk reporting of lower-level risks.

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted -

notes.author: Cameron Smith
notes.text: Strategic Vision for GRC Martene Archer is advocating for a Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) solution that moves beyond fragmented spreadsheets to deliver connected insights for decision-makers....

title: Facilities Presentation Field Based Operational Software Solution
description: Lack of Asset Mapping: Amenities are not currently mapped, making it difficult to track locations and manage service coverage effectively. Undefined Service Frequencies: Service intervals and schedules have not been formally established, leading to inconsistencies in delivery. Limited Monitoring Capabilities: There is insufficient visibility into: - On-time service delivery - Duration and timing of maintenance activities - Resource allocation and requirements Performance Management Constraints: The absence of structured data prevents the establishment and monitoring of team-based KPIs. Inadequate Work Documentation: There is no systematic method for recording summaries of completed tasks at each service location. Compliance Gaps: The current system does not support effective monitoring of compliance with the Council’s Public Amenities Strategy 2021.
businessJustification: Objective: To enhance operational efficiency, transparency, and accountability in the delivery of facilities presentation services by implementing a digital platform that supports real-time recording, monitoring, and review of completed works. - Digital Work Order System Assign, track, and close work requests in real time. Include fields for service type, location, duration, and completion notes. - Mobile Field Access Enable field teams to log completed tasks via mobile devices. Capture photos, timestamps, and notes on-site. - Interactive Amenity Mapping Visualise all public amenities with service history overlays. Filter by location, service type, or frequency. - Automated Reporting & Dashboards Generate daily, weekly, and monthly reports on completed works. Monitor KPIs such as service timeliness, duration, and compliance. - Cross-Departmental Integration Share data with City Works, Customer Service Centre, and Finance. - Compliance Monitoring Align service records with the Public Amenities Strategy 2021. Flag missed or overdue services for review.

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - To enhance operational efficiency, transparency, and accountability in the delivery of facilities presentation services by implementing a digital platform that supports real-time recording, monitoring, and review of completed works.

title: Vegetation Maintenance (Precinct) Updated Software Solution
description: The current ESRI-based solution was implemented prior to the 2019 restructure of the Horticulture and Mowing teams. While it has supported the teams in mapping individual jobs and tracking service frequency, its functionality has become increasingly limited. The system uses color-coded mapping to visually represent service delivery performance, distinguishing between on-time and overdue tasks. However, its reporting capabilities are outdated and insufficient for current operational needs. To compensate, the City Presentation team relies on a combination of the existing ESRI platform and Microsoft Excel to establish and monitor monthly and annual key performance indicators (KPIs) across precinct teams. This includes tracking metrics such as the total square meters serviced each month. Key limitations of the current system include: Inability to track the number of jobs completed or the volume of customer requests received (only those actioned are recorded). Lack of integration with rainfall data, which is instead managed through a separate sports field application. No functionality to map or incorporate new assets under development (e.g., roadside mowing sites, parks) that will be transferred to Council via developers. These constraints significantly hinder forward planning and resource allocation, particularly as the city continues to grow and new maintenance responsibilities emerge.
businessJustification: A modernised, live solution would: Support Strategic Alignment: Ensure vegetation maintenance activities are aligned with Council’s strategic goals and service standards. Enable Cross-Departmental Collaboration: Serve as a shared platform for multiple departments—including City Works, Environmental Services (ES), Development Assessment and Compliance (DAC), Customer Service, and Asset Management—enhancing transparency and coordination. Promote a Customer-Centric Approach: Improve responsiveness to community needs by enabling real-time tracking of service delivery and customer requests. Enhance Operational Oversight: Provide live dashboards and reporting tools to monitor the status of vegetation services, identify gaps, and support evidence-based decision-making. By investing in a more capable and intelligent solution, Council can improve service efficiency, enhance community satisfaction, and better plan for future growth and asset management. Improved functionality of the solution is core to the success of the project, particularly reporting functions that align with the teams operational needs

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - To enhance the existing Vegetation maintenance solution to improve

title: Estimating Solution/Benchmark
description: Currently, LMCC uses the software platform Benchmark for project delivery estimates across various departments. This platform is being phased out in favour of a new cloud-based system, while the version currently used by Council is no longer being actively supported. As a result, annual licensing fees have increased significantly. Given Council’s operational dependency on this type of software, there is currently limited capacity to assess or implement alternative solutions, leaving Council in a reactive position regarding escalating costs.
businessJustification: The software will be utilised, as it is currently a functional requirement. Success will be measured in 'usability'

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - to replace existing solution benchmark used for estimation / It is already in 25/26

title: Council On Call System
description: A number of council department have an after hours on-call process. i.e. City Works (Roads, Veg, buildings), Rangers, Waste, Safety etc. All are following their own process for transferring between on call officers and recording call details and actions resulting from calls. A single solution would enable everyone to know who is on call from each section. If there is someone out on a call that person could be called by other department to respond to a call for them saving a second person being called out. Would also enable better data that could be analysed for trends or training. Also, the transfer of the on-call number between on-call officers often creates issues. A better sloution for this process would also be usefull.
businessJustification: Reduction in overtime paid for call outs. Increase in response time to call outs. Reduced time taken for On call offices to find the right contact person for a issue not related to their section.

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - To streamline the after hour son call process and reduce the payout rates

title: Asset Inspection Process Review
description: The current road asset inspection process appears largely manual and resource-intensive, relying heavily on periodic visual assessments, reactive defect reporting, and limited integration with real-time data.  This approach presents several challenges: Inefficiency and Resourcing: Manual inspections consume significant staff time and limit the frequency and coverage of the network that can be assessed, particularly following natural disasters when resources are already stretched. Data Gaps for DRFA Claims: Post-disaster damage assessments are time-sensitive and currently lack consistent, geo-tagged photographic records of road defects, making it harder to substantiate claims under the Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements (DRFA). Lack of Real-Time Visibility: Without continuous data collection, defects can go undetected until they worsen or are reported by the public, which delays intervention and increases repair costs. Missed Opportunities for Proactive Maintenance: The current process limits our ability to identify early signs of deterioration and program works proactively, increasing long-term asset risks and reactive maintenance demands. These limitations are impacting our ability to maintain optimal service levels across the road network, particularly in the context of climate-related weather events and increasing community expectations.
businessJustification: Automated Road Defect Detection AI system successfully detects and classifies road defects (e.g. potholes, cracking, faded lines) across 80–100% of targeted road network within pilot area. Integration with Asset Management System (AMS) Defect data is automatically integrated into Council’s AMS, reducing manual data entry and improving work order generation. Reduction in Manual Inspection Hours Staff inspection hours reduced by at around 30% in areas where automated collection is active. Disaster Recovery Support Accurate, time-stamped defect data used to support at least one DRFA funding application or acquittal process. Success will also be evaluated through: Positive feedback from field staff and asset managers Reduction in reactive customer complaints for known defects Demonstrated ability to triage and prioritise defects faster and more effectively

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - To improve the defect related process using AI and Vaisala

title: Legal
description: Opportunity or problem: The Legal Team's core IT systems require updating to meet expectations of internal customers and Council’s ongoing business improvement efforts.The legal team’s main systems are: 	• Practice Evolve (2016): Practice Evolve (2016): File and document management/PE does some reporting + order company and property searches which is 3rd party plug in "Infotrack"<it is nice to have>/For external lawyer- file in PE as well / via email / Usually someone is helping from legal and updating the PE as it cant be accessed by external parties. In many cases the departments themselves interract with the external lawyers. They will put that in TRIM cant update PE / Law firms cant also update the file PE 	• Authority CRM (2017): Matter intake/ online form also but not much takers/ emails or calls > if it is received. .sent to group inbox daily standups >then open a file in PE and get a number.. Use that id for tracking and any comms.. 	• MS Forms (2021): Customer satisfaction 	• MS Excel (2020): Time tracking and reporting 	• MS Planner (2020): Task management-don’t use it planner any more. Manages task as they are allocated -non standard approach 	• DocuSign (2022): Digital signatures Challenges : Heavy reliance on email for task tracking: File management using Practice Evolve is heavily dependent on emails being appropriately filed. Ensuring filing is up to date can be time consuming, especially when it is not attended to consistently. The focus on email as the primary means of information exchange can lead to staff viewing their inbox as a de facto task list, which can impede use of the task management system, leading to it being out of date and hence less useful. Also, in large matters the sheer volume of emails can make it time consuming to find key documents and hard to obtain a quick overview of what the matter is about. Manual monthly reporting:Data from these systems is used to generate monthly reports that are the primary mechanism for sharing details of aggregate activity to individual departments, OLT and the Executive. The production of these reports is a manual process that requires a significant input from the Legal Team Administrator and individual team members. Individual matter level reporting is provided as needed to customers, primarily through email and/or direct conversations. This is a manual process that can be time consuming and is critically dependant on the input of the individual team members who are working on the matter concerned. The task management system is not granular enough to enable customers or management to obtain real time status updates without engaging directly with the person working on the matter. The use of a patchwork of multiple systems feels overly complex for a small team (8 people). This appears to be contributing to team frustrations with processes that are showing up in pulse surveys. Additionally, current systems are unable to support improvement initiatives that are being pursued by internal customers without significant and complex background development (eg: streamlining property transactions, improved contract management). How is the business need being met: There is currently no process in place to meet the business need • External contractors cant view /access PE<Nice to have>
businessJustification: • Reduced system complexity • Improved reporting and analytics • Enhanced internal customer experience • Reduced reliance on email • Improved compliance and legal privilege protection

statusHistory.notes: OTI submitted - Update Legal team’s core IT systems to meet expectations of internal customers and align with ongoing business improvement efforts.
